snippet: In a sharp escalation of tensions Monday, Egyptian soldiers opened fire on hundreds of supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, witnesses said. The military said armed assailants fired first.
abstract: Mass shooting of Islamist protesters by Egyptian security forces at sit-in for ousted president Mohamed Morsi injects new outrage into standoff over his removal by Egypt’s top generals; scale and nature of killings drives deeper wedge between Morsi’s Islamist backers and their opponents, and diminishes chances that his allies in Muslim Brotherhood might soon be coaxed back into political process they deem illegitimate.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Ben Hubbard, Mayy El Sheikh, Asmaa Al Zohairy and Sarah Mousa from Cairo, and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: In a sharp escalation of tensions Monday, Egyptian soldiers opened fire on hundreds of supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, witnesses said. The military said armed assailants fired first.

headline.sub:
Morsi Supporters
and Military Trade
Blame Over Attack
headline.main: Army Kills 51, Deepening Crisis in Egypt
headline.print_headline: Killing of Islamists Deepens Crisis in Egypt
